prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Remedies for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: A declaration is not available as of right, but is a discretionary remedy. It will not be granted unless there is a breach or threatened or intended breach of an agreement.[1] A declaration can be a useful remedy for obtaining a court judgment where no contract exists or where the party seeking relief is not a party to any existing contract.[2] A request for declaratory relief does not preclude a party from seeking any other relief.

In Marion White Ltd. v. Francis,[3] the plaintiff sought a declaration concerning a covenant that had expired before the case could be heard. Nevertheless, the employer had an interest in resolving the issue because the remaining employees were employed under contracts containing a similar clause.

A declaration was granted in Greer v. Sketchley Ltd.,[4] where the plaintiff wanted to join a rival company of the defendants. He had been employed by the defendants for many years. The defendants took the position that, in joining the rival company, the plaintiff would be in breach of a restraint of trade clause in his employment contract. Instead of joining the rival, the plaintiff commenced an action claiming a declaration that the clause was invalid. The defendants counterclaimed for an injunction. Lord Denning held that the restraint of trade clause should be declared invalid. This case demonstrates that the sympathy of the court may be a decisive factor.[5]
